EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

Eli Lilly and Company (Lilly), a global research-based pharmaceutical corporation, is dedicated to delivering innovative pharmaceutical-based healthcare solutions that enable people to live longer, healthier and more active lives.  Lilly del Caribe manufactures human health products at its Mayagüez facility.  The Mayagüez facility began operations in 1966.  The Mayagüez facility is located on a 59-acre site and includes 26 buildings.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Lilly del Caribe has designed and implemented, including:

          ¤   Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
          ¤   The stationary source and regulated substances handled
          ¤   The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario, including administrative  
               controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario
          ¤   The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps
          ¤   Five-year accident history
          ¤   The emergency response program
          ¤   Planned changes to improve safety

I.   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

     Lilly del Caribe is committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner.
     This is especially important for those processes using hazardous substances.  The Mayagüez facility 
     has comprehensive accident prevention policies which involve a united approach that integrates
     procedures, technology and management practices to ensure the safety of employees and the public, 
     as well as protection of the environment.  All applicable procedures are developed following the
     applicable OSHA and EPA requirements.

     Lilly del Caribe's Emergency Response Policy includes the implementation of a response plan, which is
     tailored to the facility and to

the emergency response services available in the community.  The 
     emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of local authorities and notification of 
     any potentially affected neighbors.

II.   THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDED:

     The Lilly del Caribe facility in Mayagüez manufactures bulk drug substances for human health 
     products.  The following regulated substance is handled at the Lilly del Caribe Mayagüez facility in a 
     quantity above the threshold quantity established under the RMP regulations.

     TOXICS

     CHEMICAL                         QUANTITY                                     USE
     Bromine                 22,500 Kg (50,000 pounds)           pharmaceutical mfg.

     FLAMMABLES - None

III.  THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO, INCLUDING 
     ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCE FOR EACH 
     REPORTED SCENARIO:  

     EPA's RMP rule requires that Lilly del Caribe provide information about the worst-case release scenario 
     and alternative release scenarios or the facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, 
     including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure
     distance for each scenario:

     Worst-Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical - Bromine

     Lilly del Caribe uses bromine in pharmaceutical manufacturing.  The worst case scenario at the Lilly del 
     Caribe facility in Mayagüez involves the rupture of the storage tank containing 22,500 Kg (50,000 lbs.) 
     of bromine and creating a pool in the diked area surrounding the tank.  According to the EPA's RMP 
     Comp and EPA's standard weather conditions, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 6.2 miles.  
     Approximately 140,000 residents may be affected by this release.

     Alternative-Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical - Bromine

     In order to participate in CMA's Responsible Care *R* program, Lilly del Caribe has committed to meet 
     these guidelines and incorporate them into the way it does business.   All Lilly sites regulated by the 
     Environmental Protection Agency (Indiana and Puerto Rico sites) participate in this national program. 
     Similar programs have also been initiated in European and Canadian plants.  The heart of the 
     Responsible Care initiative is the six Codes of Management Practices:

     COMMUNITY AWARENESS & EMERGENCY RESPONSE
     Goal:  Ensure emergency preparedness and foster community right-to-know

     EMPLOYEE HEALTH AND SAFETY
     Goal:  Protect the health and safety of employees and people visiting company sites

     POLLUTION PREVENTION
     Goal:  Promote efforts to protect the environment by generating less waste and reducing emissions

     PROCESS SAFETY
     Goal:  Prevent fires, explosings and accidental releases

     DISTRIBUTION:
     Goal:  Reduce the risk to public carriers, customers, contractors, employees and environment posed by 
     the transportation and storage of chemicals 

     PRODUCTION STEWARDSHIP
     Goal:  Promote the safe handling of chemicals and products frominitial manufacture to distribution, sale

and ultimate disposal

     Lilly del Caribe is proud to participate in this forward-looking industry initiative.  It is one way Lilly can
     demonstrate its commitment to ensuring the safety of its employee and the community and to protecting
     the environment.

V.  FIVE - YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

      Lilly del Caribe Mayagüez facility has had no accidents as defined in 40 CFR 68.42 during the past five
      years.

VI.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

      The facility has an emergency response program, which has been shared with the Puerto Rico Fire
      Department, Añasco Civil Defense, Mayagüez Civil Defense and the Puerto Rico Environmental Quality
      Board. This program includes an Emergency Response Team, Emergency Response Management 
      Team, Emergency Response Vehicle and Emergemcy Response Equipment Storage Facilities. The
      emergency brigade members are trained in Florida and Texas for fire fighting and spill contaiment. 
      Routine drills are done at the facilities three to four times a year. Emergency procedures are in place 
      and revised accordingly to emergency response drill and feedback information.

VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

       Lilly del caribe is committed to ongoing safety improvement. A system to conduct Process Hazard 
       Assessments is in place. The system will assure Process Hazard Assesments are conducted for 
      each of the appropriate processes at the Mayagüez facility.

       The mechanical systems are routinely tested to ensure proper operation and performance.  Any 
       problems found are corrected and opportunities for improvement are noted and evaluated.

       Practice drills are also conducted to practice and improve the procedures for responding to 
       emergencies.

IV. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION
     STEPS:

     Lilly del Caribe is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management requirements, as well as other OSHA 
     requirements.  The facility is also subject to regulation by other agencies, including the United States 
     Environmental Protection Agency and the Puerto Rico Environmental Quality Board.

     Specific prevention programs include conducting pre-startup and design hazard assessments, 
     proactive maintenance programs, routine vessel inspections, emergency response training, safe to 
     work programs, employee and contractor safety programs, and accident investigation programs.
